places.title: Quattro Canti
places.description: The beating heart of Palermo, Piazza Quattro Canti is a magnificent example of Sicilian Baroque. Here the four main streets of the city intersect, surrounded by splendid decorated facades.
places.fullDescription: Also called Piazza Vigliena and known as the 'Theatre of the Sun', Quattro Canti is a surprising monumental crossroads designed between 1608 and 1620. The four concave facades that define the square are decorated with fountains, allegories of the seasons, statues of Spanish rulers and the patron saints of the historic districts. The overall composition transforms the crossroads into a theatrical octagon: it is the ideal point from which to start exploring Palermo‚Äôs historic center and understand the city‚Äôs architectural layering.

places.title: San Giovanni degli Eremiti
places.description: A jewel of Norman architecture, famous for its red domes and the peaceful atmosphere of its gardens. An ideal place to immerse yourself in Palermo‚Äôs millennial history.
places.fullDescription: San Giovanni degli Eremiti, whose origin dates back to the 12th century, is an emblematic example of the encounter between Norman art and Arab influences. The distinctive red domes, the cloister with twin columns, and the tranquil inner garden offer a secluded atmosphere that contrasts with the energy of the city center. The complex, near the Norman Palace, tells the complex cultural history of medieval Palermo.

places.title: Piazza Pretoria
places.description: Famous for its imposing monumental fountain, Piazza Pretoria is a symbol of the city. The marble statues and surrounding architecture create a suggestive and romantic atmosphere.
places.fullDescription: Piazza Pretoria is dominated by the monumental Pretoria Fountain, a Renaissance masterpiece originally from Florence and transferred to Palermo at the end of the 16th century. The fountain is rich with statues of deities, nymphs, and allegorical figures‚Äîhence the nickname 'Fountain of Shame'. Around it stand Palazzo Pretorio (the Town Hall), the Church of Santa Caterina, and other historic palaces: it is one of the most scenic and photographed corners of the historic center.

places.title: Palermo Cathedral
places.description: An imposing building blending Arab, Norman, and Gothic styles. The Cathedral dominates Palermo‚Äôs skyline with its towers and millennial history, bearing witness to the many cultures that influenced the city.
places.fullDescription: The Palermo Cathedral, founded in the 12th century and remodeled in various periods, is a true stone book on the island‚Äôs history: Arab-Norman, Gothic, Baroque, and Neoclassical elements coexist in its structures. Inside are royal tombs (including members of the Swabian dynasty) and a rich liturgical treasure. Climbing to the terraces offers a striking view of the historic center and the surrounding mountains.
